newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Canada clinches veterinary accord with EU.
newsitem.headline: Canada clinches veterinary accord with EU.

text.p: Canada has reached agreement in principle with the European Union on the mutual recognition of veterinary and plant health standards, Canadian officials said on Friday.
"It's a very important step in facilitating trade in agricultural and fisheries products," said a Canadian official.
European Commission officials could not immediately be reached for comment.
The agreement, which is subject to final scrutiny and ratification by both sides, is the second concluded by the EU following one with New Zealand in December.
The European Commission is seeking new veterinary agreements with its main trading partners by April 1, 1997.
The agreements will be based on sanitary and phytosanitary measures adopted under the GATT Uruguay Round of world trade talks and involve harmonisation of import rules in the 15 EU member states.

An EU delegation is due to hold a further round of talks with the U.S. in Washington on March 24 after making little progress in Brussels this week, EU sources said, adding problems include American meat and pountry exports.
Washington wants to be given BSE-free status as no cases of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) have been reported in U.S. but it has not given the guarantees demanded by Brussels.
The U.S. says that its cattle tracking and monitoring systems are much better than those in most EU member states.
Brussels is also concerned about the hygiene and safety of U.S. poultry-meat production methods.
U.S. officials declined to make any official comment.
The EU is due next week to hold another round of veterinary talks with Australia, with whom talks are at an advanced stage.
